snippet: A officer's wedding offers insight into Civil War Army politics.
abstract: A officer's wedding offers insight into Civil War Army politics.
lead_paragraph: Sam Oliver was going to be married. The recently widowed lieutenant colonel, 35 years old, had proposed to a young lady back home in Massachusetts and she accepted. Now he just needed to get time off from his duties along the Virginia section of the Washington defenses. On New Year's Day 1862, he applied by letter for a three-week furlough. He submitted it to his commanding colonel, William Greene, who was pleased to comply - not because he wanted Oliver's happiness, but because he wanted to get rid of him.
